title: 106_s1346
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Office of Advocacy Act". Congress acknowledges the burden of excessive regulations on small businesses and the reluctance of Federal agencies to comply with regulatory requirements. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is recognized as an effective advocate for small businesses, needing independence and sufficient resources to fulfill its role. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is crucial for advocating for small businesses independently and effectively assessing the impact of regulations. It requires sufficient resources for research and serves as a valuable advisor to Congress and executive branch agencies. The purposes of this Act are to ensure the Office of Advocacy's independence and financial resources, report to Congress and the President on small business issues, provide separate appropriations authorization, and enhance the Office's role under title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. OFFICE OF ADVOCACY. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section for the Office of Advocacy. The Office of Advocacy, established under the Small Business Act, includes the Chief Counsel appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Chief Counsel must come from civilian life and cannot have served in the Small Business Administration for five years prior to appointment. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy may be removed from office by the President, with notification to Congress, and each appropriation request must include a separate request for the Office's funding. The Office's primary functions include examining the role of small businesses in the US economy and their potential contributions to competition and economic growth. The Office's primary functions include examining the role of small businesses in the US economy and their potential contributions to competition and economic growth. The Office shall assess the effectiveness of Federal subsidy and assistance programs for small businesses and propose legislative, regulatory, and nonlegislative measures to reduce government regulation and promote small business growth. The Office of Advocacy, established under the Small Business Act, focuses on reducing emphasis on specific programs and increasing general assistance programs for all small businesses. It aims to measure and eliminate excessive government regulation, study the impact of the tax structure, assess financial markets' ability to meet small business credit needs, and recommend methods for delivering financial assistance to minority and women-owned enterprises. The Office of Advocacy, established under the Small Business Act, aims to evaluate government demands on credit for small businesses, recommend financial resource availability methods for minority and women-owned enterprises, assess Federal agencies and private sector efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, and make recommendations to strengthen small businesses. Additionally, it is tasked with recommending specific measures for creating an environment where all businesses can compete effectively, determining criteria to define small businesses, and submitting reports to relevant committees on issues affecting small businesses. The Office of Advocacy, established under the Small Business Act, serves as a focal point for receiving feedback on government policies affecting small businesses, counsels small businesses on resolving issues with the Federal Government, develops proposals for policy changes, and represents the views of small businesses. The Office of Advocacy, established under the Small Business Act, develops proposals for policy changes, represents small businesses before Federal agencies, enlists cooperation in disseminating information about government programs for small businesses, and carries out responsibilities under title 5, United States Code. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Advocacy can appoint additional personnel without following civil service laws, set their compensation, and not exceed a certain pay rate. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Advocacy has the authority to appoint additional personnel, set their compensation, and procure temporary services as needed. The pay rates should not exceed the maximum rate for a position at GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Chief Counsel can consult with experts in various fields to carry out these duties effectively. The Chief Counsel can also request necessary information from Federal agencies and submit annual reports to the President and the Committees on Small Business of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Advocacy can request information from Federal agencies and submit annual reports to the President and relevant committees. Additionally, the Chief Counsel may prepare and publish additional reports as deemed appropriate. No report can be submitted to other government departments before being sent to the President. Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed, and the incumbent Chief Counsel for Advocacy will continue in their position. The Senate passed the bill on November 5, 1999. Attest: GARY SISCO, Secretary.
